'''Leland Wilkinson''' (born {{abbr|c.|circa}} 1945) is a [[statistician]] and [[computer scientist]] at [[Tableau Software]] and Adjunct Professor of Computer Science at University of Illinois at Chicago. Dr. Wilkinson developed the SYSTAT statistical package in the early 1980s, sold it to SPSS in 1995, and worked at SPSS for 10 years recruiting and managing the visualization team. He left SPSS in 2008 and became Executive VP of SYSTAT Software Inc. in Chicago. He then served as the VP of Data Visualization at [[Skytree, Inc]], and joined Tableau in October 2014. His research focuses on [[scientific visualization]] and [[statistical graphics]].

==Family life==
He is the son of Mr. and Mrs Kirk C. Wilkinson.<ref>[http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20C12FA3F5C107B93C6AB178DD85F438685F9] "Ruth VanDemark becomes a bride." New York Times, June 24, 1967.</ref> He is brother of [[Alec Wilkinson]], a writer for New Yorker. He was married to Reverend Ruth VanDemark, who died in 2012, and is the father of [[Amie Wilkinson]], a professor of mathematics at [[University of Chicago]], and Caroline Wilkinson, a writer. He married Marilyn Vogel, an attorney, in 2013.

==Education and academic work==

Wilkinson received an A.B. from [[Harvard University]] in 1966, an S.T.B. from [[Harvard Divinity School]] in 1969, and a Ph.D. in Psychology from [[Yale University]] in 1975.  In the 1970s and 1980s, he was a full-time faculty member at [[University of Illinois at Chicago]] (UIC). After serving 10 years as Adjunct Professor of Statistics at [[Northwestern University]], he rejoined UIC as Adjunct Professor of Computer Science.

Dr. Wilkinson is recognized as the primary author of the 1999 American Psychological Association's Guidelines for Statistical Methods in Psychology Journals.

==Professional career==

Wilkinson wrote SYSTAT, a statistical software package, in the early 1980s.<ref>http://www.systat.com</ref> This program was noted for its comprehensive graphics,<ref>http://www.springerlink.com/content/x4u4r25k41l717l6/</ref> including the first software implementation of the [[heatmap]] display now widely used among biologists. After his company grew to 50 employees, he sold it to [[SPSS]] in 1995. At SPSS, he assembled a team of graphics programmers who developed the nViZn platform <ref>http://www.galaxy.gmu.edu/interface/I01/I2001Proceedings/LJones/LJones.pdf</ref> that produces the visualizations in [[SPSS]], [[SPSS Modeler|Clementine]], and other analytics products. The nViZn platform was modeled after Wilkinson's 1999 book on statistical graphics, ''The Grammar of Graphics''.<ref>Leland Wilkinson, ''The Grammar of Graphics'', Springer, 1999. ISBN 0-387-98774-6. [http://www.springer.com/statistics/computational/book/978-0-387-24544-7 at Springer]</ref> This book also served as the foundation for the [[R (programming language)|R]] package [[ggplot2]],<ref>http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggplot2/index.html</ref> the Python Bokeh package,<ref name=Bokeh>{{cite web|title=Bokeh|url=https://github.com/ContinuumIO/Bokeh|publisher=Github|accessdate=17 July 2013}}</ref> the R package ggbio,<ref name=ggbio>{{cite web|last=Lawrence|first=Michael|title=ggbio: an R package for extending the grammar of graphics for genomic data|url=http://genomebiology.com/2012/13/8/R77|publisher=Genome Biology|accessdate=17 July 2013}}</ref> and helped shape the Polaris project at Stanford.<ref>http://www.graphics.stanford.edu/projects/polaris/</ref>  Wilkinson now serves as VP of Statistics at [[Tableau Software]].

==Awards==

Wilkinson is a Fellow of the [[American Statistical Association]], a Fellow of the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]], and an elected member of the [[International Statistical Institute]].
